channel.title: Flashback
channel.description: Not all tech products succeed once on the market, and some are killed off with little warning. Flashback looked back at failed tech products to see what we can learn by studying their demises. Hosted by Quinn Nelson and Stephen Hackett.
channel.itunes:author: Relay

item.title: 25: On PC Clones & The End of the Road for IBM’s Personal Computer Business
item.description: IBM quickly lost control of the market it had helped create, going from industry-leader to quietly exiting the personal computer business in just a couple of decades.
item.itunes:title: On PC Clones & The End of the Road for IBM’s Personal Computer Business
item.itunes:author: Quinn Nelson and Stephen Hackett
item.itunes:subtitle: IBM quickly lost control of the market it had helped create, going from industry-leader to quietly exiting the personal computer business in just a couple of decades.
item.itunes:summary: IBM quickly lost control of the market it had helped create, going from industry-leader to quietly exiting the personal computer business in just a couple of decades.
item.content:encoded:
IBM quickly lost control of the market it had helped create, going from industry-leader to quietly exiting the personal computer business in just a couple of decades.

item.title: 24: Later IBM PC Models
item.description: The first IBM PC kicked off what would be a line of computers that would be sold through the 1980s. This week, Quinn and Stephen hit the high points of this beige wave.

item.itunes:author: Quinn Nelson and Stephen Hackett

item.title: 23: IBM's Search for an Operating System
item.description: With its PC built, IBM needed to find an operating system that would run on it. Its choice would change the computer industry forever.
item.itunes:title: IBM's Search for an Operating System
item.itunes:author: Quinn Nelson and Stephen Hackett
item.itunes:subtitle: With its PC built, IBM needed to find an operating system that would run on it. Its choice would change the computer industry forever.

item.content:encoded:

item.title: 22: Building the Personal Computer
item.description: The IBM Personal Computer was developed in a shockingly short period of time. This time, Quinn and Stephen discuss the machine's hardware as well as some of the company's earlier attempts at personal computers.

item.title: 21: The International Business Machines Corporation
item.description: This season on Flashback, Quinn and Stephen are covering the rise — and fall — of IBM's PC business, but first: some background on the enormous company that Apple and so many others lived in the shadow of back in the 80s.

item.title: 20: Windows Vista
item.description: The story of Windows Vista is a complicated one. Born from a long and troubled development cycle, it wasn't free of problems at launch, but hardware OEMs and others didn't do much to help its reputation.

item.title: 17: The Palm Foleo
item.description:
A phone. An email terminal. A web-browsing portable companion. A phone. An email terminal. A web-browsing portable companion. A phone. An email terminal. A web-browsing portable companion. A phone. An email terminal. A web-browsing portable companion.
Are you getting it? These are not three devices.
It's two devices, and we're calling them your Palm phone and Foleo.
item.itunes:title: The Palm Foleo
item.itunes:author: Quinn Nelson and Stephen Hackett
item.itunes:subtitle:
A phone. An email terminal. A web-browsing portable companion. A phone. An email terminal. A web-browsing portable companion.
Are you getting it? These are not three devices.
It's two devices, and we're calling them your Palm phone and Foleo.

item.content:encoded:
A phone. An email terminal. A web-browsing portable companion. A phone. An email terminal. A web-browsing portable companion.

Are you getting it? These are not three devices.

It's two devices, and we're calling them your Palm phone and Foleo.

item.title: 16: ROKR: The iTunes Phone

item.title: 14: OS/2
item.description: In an effort to keep Microsoft from controlling the PC software industry, in the 1980s, IBM created OS/2, an operating system meant to give its computers a competitive advantage. Unable to do this alone, Big Blue turned to an unlikely company to help build it.
item.itunes:title: OS/2
item.itunes:author: Quinn Nelson and Stephen Hackett
item.itunes:subtitle: In an effort to keep Microsoft from controlling the PC software industry, in the 1980s, IBM created OS/2, an operating system meant to give its computers a competitive advantage.
item.itunes:summary: In an effort to keep Microsoft from controlling the PC software industry, in the 1980s, IBM created OS/2, an operating system meant to give its computers a competitive advantage.
item.content:encoded:
In an effort to keep Microsoft from controlling the PC software industry, in the 1980s, IBM created OS/2, an operating system meant to give its computers a competitive advantage.

item.title: 13: The CrunchPad

item.title: 12: The Amazon Fire Phone
item.description: This time, Quinn and Stephen look back — in 3D! — at the Amazon Fire Phone. Between its operating system, unusual gesture system and a price that was way too high, it was dead on arrival. After that, the guys go shopping for each other, picking out some unusual products that bear Amazon's name today.
item.itunes:title: The Amazon Fire Phone
item.itunes:author: Quinn Nelson and Stephen Hackett
item.itunes:subtitle: This time, Quinn and Stephen look back — in 3D! — at the Amazon Fire Phone. Between its operating system, unusual gesture system and a price that was way too high, it was dead on arrival. After that, the guys go shopping for each other on Amazon.

item.title: 11: The Nexus Q
item.description: In 2012, Google announced a sphere-shaped media player that was meant to be used with a TV or sound system. It was a disaster. However, nearly a decade later, set-top boxes are nearly everywhere. How did the market move past a weird Google product to offer a wide range of compelling products?
item.itunes:title: The Nexus Q
item.itunes:author: Quinn Nelson and Stephen Hackett
item.itunes:subtitle: In 2012, Google announced a sphere-shaped media player that was meant to be used with a TV or sound system. It was a disaster.

item.content:encoded:

item.title: 10: Pebble
item.description: The smartwatch movement didn't start with Apple or Google, but a little company named Pebble. Through a series of hugely successful Kickstarters, the company put out several well-reviewed products before being steamrolled by the platform-makers.

item.title: 9: The Apple III
item.description: The Apple II was a big hit, but before the Macintosh took over, Cupertino shipped a couple of duds, the worst of which was the ill-fated (and kinda melty) Apple III.

item.title: 8: The Microsoft Kin
item.description: Microsoft was late to the smartphone party, and its first entrance, the Kin, was designed for teens and young adults who didn't want or need an iPhone, Android phone or Blackberry. The only problem? That audience didn't really exist.

item.title: 6: The Be Computer Company
item.description: Started by former members of Apple's leadership team, Be was formed to take on the Mac and other computers of the mid-90s. The company wrote its own operating system and shipped dual-CPU towers before failing to be bought by Apple and slowly fading away.

item.title: 4: webOS
item.description: With its webOS hardware, including the Pre, Pixi and more, Palm (and later HP) tried to take on the giants of the early smartphone wars. While webOS was hugely innovative, it wasn't enough to break into the most important market in consumer electronics history.

item.title: 3: The GM EV1
item.description: Electric cars may seem like a 21st century phenomenon, but they are far from modern invention. Along the winding path to the present was the GM EV1, the first purpose-designed electric vehicle. It went on sale in 1996, but within a decade, General Motors had recalled and crushed almost all of them.
item.itunes:title: The GM EV1
item.itunes:author: Quinn Nelson and Stephen Hackett
item.itunes:subtitle: Electric cars may seem like 21st century tech, but they are far from modern invention. Along the winding path to the present was the GM EV1, the first purpose-designed electric vehicle. It went on sale in 1996, but were all crushed within 10 years.
item.itunes:summary: Electric cars may seem like 21st century tech, but they are far from modern invention. Along the winding path to the present was the GM EV1, the first purpose-designed electric vehicle. It went on sale in 1996, but were all crushed within 10 years.
item.content:encoded:
Electric cars may seem like 21st century tech, but they are far from modern invention. Along the winding path to the present was the GM EV1, the first purpose-designed electric vehicle. It went on sale in 1996, but were all crushed within 10 years.

item.title: 2: The Microsoft Zune
item.description: In the 2000s, the iPod was a true juggernaut, simply dominating the portable music player market. Microsoft wanted a piece of the pie, and launched the Zune 30, which eventually spread into a line of both hardware products and software services. However, it barely made a dent in Apple's commanding lead. This episode, Quinn and Stephen look into why the folks from Seattle failed so hard at taking on the iPod.

item.title: 1: The Newton
item.description: Today, Apple is well known for its mobile devices like the iPhone and iPad, but in the 1990s, the Macintosh-only company invented the Personal Digital Assistant. Its PDA was the Newton, a family of handwriting-based devices that promised mobile productivity. However, after five short years, the whole line was cancelled. This episode, Stephen and Quinn revisit the Newton and talk about what — and who — killed it.
item.itunes:title: The Newton
item.itunes:author: Quinn Nelson and Stephen Hackett
item.itunes:subtitle: Today, Apple is well known for its mobile devices like the iPhone and iPad, but in the 1990s, the Macintosh-only company invented the Personal Digital Assistant. However, after five short years, the whole Newton line was cancelled.

Today, Apple is well known for its mobile devices like the iPhone and iPad, but in the 1990s, the Macintosh-only company invented the Personal Digital Assistant. However, after five short years, the whole Newton line was cancelled.
